sectionTitle: C.1: Jain Ascetics: Sädhu and Sädhvi

tabData.tagHTML: The Jain Sangh (four-fold order) consists of Sädhus (monks), Sädhvis (nuns), Shrävaks (laymen), and Shrävikäs (laywomen). When a person renounces all worldly attachments and responsibilities by taking Dikshä, they become a Sädhu or Sädhvi. They are completely detached from social and worldly activities, dedicating their lives to spiritual upliftment and guiding laypeople.

To achieve liberation, one must follow the path of Ratna-trayi: Right Faith, Right Knowledge, and Right Conduct. The foundation of Right Conduct for ascetics is the observance of the five Mahävrat, or great vows.

tabData.title: The Five Great Vows (Mahävrat)
tabData.description: These are the five major vows that Jain ascetics must follow completely and strictly in mind, speech, and body.

cards.back: Absolute Non-violence. Complete renunciation of harming, hurting, or causing pain to any living being, mobile or immobile.
Absolute Truth. Complete renunciation of all forms of false speech arising from anger, greed, fear, or jest.
Absolute Non-stealing. Complete renunciation of taking anything, no matter how small or valueless, that is not given by its owner.
Absolute Celibacy/Chastity. Complete renunciation of all sensuous and sexual activities of any kind.
Absolute Non-attachment/Non-possessiveness. Complete renunciation of all attachments to people, places, and material things.

tabData.title: Daily Practices of an Ascetic
tabData.description: In addition to the five great vows, Sädhus and Sädhvis follow many other strict rules.

items.content: Jain ascetics do not cook or possess food. They practice Gochari, accepting small, pure vegetarian portions from multiple households, just as a cow grazes without depleting any single patch of grass. This ensures they are not the cause of any cooking-related violence.

Ascetics always travel barefoot to avoid harming any living beings. They do not use vehicles. They do not stay in one place for more than a few days (except during the four-month rainy season, Chäturmäs) to avoid developing attachments.

At their initiation (Dikshä) and at least once a year thereafter, ascetics pluck out their hair by hand. This practice, called Kesha-lochan, is an austerity that demonstrates forbearance of pain with complete equanimity.

Digambar monks are sky-clad (wear no clothes) and carry a Morpichhi (peacock-feather broom) and a Kamandal (wooden water pot). Shvetämbar monks and nuns wear simple, unstitched white cotton clothes and carry an Ogho or Rajoharan (woolen broom) and a Muhapatti (cloth to cover the mouth).

tabData.title: Hierarchy of Spiritual Attainment
tabData.description: As ascetics advance in their spiritual study and practice, they may be conferred with special titles by their Guru.

items.content: A Sädhu must have in-depth knowledge of specific Jain Ägams, such as the Bhagavati Sutra, to attain these ranks.
This title is given to a Sädhu who has mastered all Jain scriptures and other philosophical systems. Their primary role is to teach other ascetics and laypeople.
This is the highest rank and spiritual head of a Jain congregation. An Ächärya has profound scriptural knowledge and spiritual excellence, and they lead the entire four-fold Sangh.
This is a title conferred upon Sädhvis who have attained deep knowledge of certain Ägam Sutras, such as the Ächäränga Sutra.
